title: Recherche clinique à l’IHU de Marseille : « En l’absence de réaction des institutions, les graves manquements constatés pourraient devenir la norme »

last_post.content: "La médiatisation sans recul critique, sous un jour favorable, de ces mauvaises pratiques a largement contribué à alimenter la défiance de certains de nos concitoyens envers la science, la recherche clinique, les autorités sanitaires et les experts en général. Dans le contexte particulièrement anxiogène de cette crise sanitaire, les propos péremptoires proclamant l’efficacité de ces traitements ont, malheureusement, rencontré un large succès dans le public" https://www.lemonde.fr/sciences/article/2023/05/28/recherche-clinique-a-l-ihu-de-marseille-en-l-absence-de-reaction-des-institutions-les-graves-manquements-constates-pourraient-devenir-la-norme_6175184_1650684.html

For years I have been assuming my life is a long corridor that inexorably leads to a single place, and that single place is making a gradually-typed interpreted/JIT Rust-ABI-compatible Rust variant. I have wanted this to exist so badly, for years, I assumed I would have to make it happen myself. But then I found out last week about Rhai ( https://rhai.rs/ ) and it is… good… actually it appears to be *very* good… … so, maybe I just use Rhai

Any case you were all curious, this was what I was looking for.

https://youtu.be/GaoLU6zKaws

We at @investinopen are thrilled to launch the Open Infrastructure Fund pilot, which offers 5-25k USD to projects that strengthen resilience + increase adoption of open infra underpinning research & scholarship.

What we fund:
1️⃣ Capacity building
2️⃣ Strengthening community governance
3️⃣ Critical shared infrastructure

60% of the funds available for those in/ serving Low + Middle Income Economies (LMIEs).

Tech layoffs ravage the teams that fight online misinformation and hate speech https://cnb.cx/3OHIIaX Meta, Amazon, Alphabet and Twitter have all drastically reduced the size of their teams focused on internet trust and safety as well as ethics as the companies focus on cost cuts.
As part of Meta’s mass layoffs, the company ended a fact-checking project that had taken half a year to build, according to people familiar with the matter.
“Abuse actors are usually ahead of the game; it’s cat and mouse,” said Arjun Narayan, who previously served as a trust and safety lead at Google and ByteDance. #socialmedia #moderation #hatespeech #abuse #misinformation

title: How to Read an Aztec "Comic": Indigenous Knowledge, Mothers' Bodies, and Tamales in the Pot

last_post.content:
I must say I'm absolutely in love with the Aztec jadeite/nephrite designs for Zonai gear in Zelda Tears of the Kingdom.

Artist-goddess @monarobot is my savior when it comes to art in the classic #Maya style. I need to find artists who work in that #Aztec and #Zapotec style.

Felicia Rhapsody Lopez and Jordan Collver's graphic novel-slash-academic paper (🤩!), 'How to Read an Aztec "Comic": Indigenous Knowledge, Mothers' Bodies, and Tamales in the Pot' is fantastic but not enough! https://escholarship.org/uc/item/8cq5w8b2

(Edit, remembered that some of this looks Zapotec like this brilliant bat mask https://github.com/fasiha/10000-years-of-art#128-zapotec-bat-mask)

title: Seatown and East Beach from Prospect Terrace

title: Rapidly increasing likelihood of exceeding 50 °C in parts of the Mediterranean and the Middle East due to human influence - npj Climate and Atmospheric Science

last_post.content:
Early Warnings

In this peer-reviewed paper scientists looked at 12 locations around the Mediterranean and Middle East to determine when these locations would cross the regular occurrences of 45° and then 50°C days given our current trajectory. They look at the situation at present, mid century (27 years away) and late century (77 years away)

Source: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41612-023-00377-4

They observe:

title: Steal This Idea: In Quebec, A New Traffic Light Only Turns Green for Safe Drivers

last_post.content:
I love clever uses of incentives and tech: Cities are using traffic lights near schools that start red and turn green if an approaching car isn't speeding.

If you're good, you get to keep driving. If you're bad, you have to stop and wait for the light to turn green.

The average speed on the road almost immediately dropped to the speed limit as people learned the rules.

Instead of punishing people with tickets after the fact, it creates the behavior the city wants.

https://mass.streetsblog.org/2023/05/05/steal-this-idea-in-quebec-a-new-traffic-light-only-turns-green-for-safe-drivers/

Business: Never.

Workers: Well, what's left?!

Business: Child labor!

Sampling Postgres data in QGIS

Let's say you have a large data source and you want to roughly see what data you have, without having to pull and render every little forest path in the world (which could take forever).

You can do this by creating a custom layer and use the `TABLESAMPLE` [1] to retrieve a subset of the data.

[1] https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-select.html#SQL-FROM

#postgres #qgis

Ok, nice little social media experiment, how does the fediverse fare during an earthquake?

A midnight earthquake just hit my home city, which basically never gets earthquakes. Probably no damage at all from this one, but we all definitely felt it, which is unusual for us! (Prob ~4 on Richter scale)

Where did I go first to check if others felt it? NGL, the place I went last time there was a tremor … Twitter. And to be fair, on the top of my feed were posts from people I follow (who aren’t here) that live in my home city, tweeting about it, including links to official reports. This was very nice, as this time I was scared and thought my apartment building might be in trouble.

I quickly check #mastodon and #calckey. Nothing in timelines. Not surprising, I don’t really follow anyone or many that live in the same city as me.

Searching, mastodon’s hashtag search does ok, and surfaces a bot or two that also confirm the quake (@lastquake@masto.ai). But not many people, I’m not really finding a conversation. This is on an instance with ~50k users.

#Calckey’s full text search though (on calckey.social)?

Quicker. Just typed earthquake without worrying about hashtags.

And better results. More people were brought up, which is kinda what you’re after from social media during an event … reassurance. It was also surprising, as calckey has only ~2k users and therefore smaller visibility of the fediverse, but still gave me more connectivity just through search than my bigger mastodon instance.

Which is really an interesting demonstration of how hashtags can be problematic. Plenty of people were reaching out, asking “anyone feel that earthquake?”, they just forgot or didn’t think to use a hashtag, and so couldn’t find me through mastodon. And why would you in a (slightly) nervous situation like that. “Hmmm, is this the best hashtag, do you think people will search for it … I should probably check if it exists first?” … is not a thought goes through your mind.

I basically never visit Twitter since I left, but this was a nostalgic little episode. It was nice to see the fediverse wasn’t really behind big social. Though the lack of discovery facilities on mastodon really did show themselves here.

Ok, nice little social media experiment, how does the fediverse fare during an earthquake?

A midnight earthquake just hit my home city, which basically never gets earthquakes. Probably no damage at all from this one, but we all definitely felt it, which is unusual for us! (Prob ~4 on Richter scale)

Where did I go first to check if others felt it? NGL, the place I went last time there was a tremor … Twitter. And to be fair, on the top of my feed were posts from people I follow (who aren’t here) that live in my home city, tweeting about it, including links to official reports. This was very nice, as this time I was scared and thought my apartment building might be in trouble.

I quickly check #mastodon and #calckey. Nothing in timelines. Not surprising, I don’t really follow anyone or many that live in the same city as me.

Searching, mastodon’s hashtag search does ok, and surfaces a bot or two that also confirm the quake (@lastquake@masto.ai). But not many people, I’m not really finding a conversation. This is on an instance with ~50k users.

#Calckey’s full text search though (on calckey.social)?

Quicker. Just typed earthquake without worrying about hashtags.

And better results. More people were brought up, which is kinda what you’re after from social media during an event … reassurance. It was also surprising, as calckey has only ~2k users and therefore smaller visibility of the fediverse, but still gave me more connectivity just through search than my bigger mastodon instance.

Which is really an interesting demonstration of how hashtags can be problematic. Plenty of people were reaching out, asking “anyone feel that earthquake?”, they just forgot or didn’t think to use a hashtag, and so couldn’t find me through mastodon. And why would you in a (slightly) nervous situation like that. “Hmmm, is this the best hashtag, do you think people will search for it … I should probably check if it exists first?” … is not a thought goes through your mind.

I basically never visit Twitter since I left, but this was a nostalgic little episode. It was nice to see the fediverse wasn’t really behind big social. Though the lack of discovery facilities on mastodon really did show themselves here.

Duke Ellington Bridge, Washington, DC.

Also known as the Calvert Street Bridge, this concrete arch bridge over Rock Creek opened in 1935. It replaced a steel structure that vibrated so palpably that it was known locally as the "Jazz Bridge". Ironically, the current Ellington bridge has neither dance-inducing musical properties nor a corresponding nickname.

More pixels at https://www.flickr.com/photos/mattblaze/50314068422

Note: Vertical image. You may need to click the preview to see the whole thing.

title: Nature Reviews Physics: Science in the age of Large Language Models

last_post.content: First was a fantastic panel on using #LLMs for science at the Alan Turing Institute with @abebab, Atoosa Kasirzadeh, and @SandraWachter. The panelists are incisive and withering in their criticism of blindly applying LLMs to fields where the truth matters, as well as the tendency of industry and academia to center benefits rather than harms. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FgoT1Jygf1k (2/7)

title: Giving It All Away: My Philanthropic Plan - Jacob Kaplan-Moss

last_post.content:
Last year, my wife and I took steps to build a philanthropic plan, with the goal of giving away our wealth in our lifetime.

This was way more difficult and complex than I might have thought, so I wrote about it, in quite a bit of detail.

If you're looking to do the same, I hope this gives you some pointers:

https://jacobian.org/2023/may/15/giving-it-all-away/

@csk @OscarCunningham @divbyzero I've created a p5js sketch that illustrates how this bijection works: https://editor.p5js.org/pieter_mostert/full/3QN-hFJj7
You can find an outline of the proof here: https://mathoverflow.net/questions/443377/how-can-one-construct-a-four-coloring-of-a-tiling-of-the-plane-with-smith-myers

It would be interesting to find a set of tile matching rules for the hexagons that guarantees the tilings generated come from hat tilings. Adjacency rules for edges are not enough.

title: Depression hits suburbs more than city centres, new report claims

last_post.content:
higher risks of depression found in sprawling, low-rise suburbs "may be partly down to long car commutes, less public open space and not high enough resident density to enable many local commercial places where people can gather together".

https://www.euronews.com/next/2023/05/27/depression-more-common-in-surburban-single-family-houses-than-in-city-centres-new-report

My second week doing the Bloomberg Tax Insights intro, this one connects the debt ceiling debate with tax:

"Viewed through this metaphor, the debate can largely be reduced to one question: Does the current tax regime fairly apportion the burdens and benefits of society? If so, then taxes needn’t be raised, and we have fundamentally reached the limit of what government can provide us. If not, then something must be changed.”

#lawfedi #tax @law

title: Abandoned Home That Hasn’t Been Touched Since The 1960s

last_post.content: This urban exploration YouTube channel I follow posted a video today exploring a house they found in Westchester County, New York that's literally splitting in half, but inside is like a time capsule from the 1960s. Photo albums and diaries, 1964 World's Fair memorabilia, 1920s ephemera in the attic... But it's all gone now: the house was demolished last week "with pretty much everything inside." https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MRIGBgwErP4
